app.title: Card Box / Tray SVG Generator

faqUi.troubleshootingShort: Common symptoms and what to change.

placeholders.mechanismJustification: Why this mechanism fits your requirements

Troubleshooting.a: Common causes: draw slot too short/tight, hold-down gap too small (high friction), ramp too steep (binding), or box too wide (cards rotate). Start with the Card Shoe preset, use Normal/Loose fit, and increase draw slot height slightly.

Troubleshooting.q: Why does my candy stop flowing?
Troubleshooting.a: Flowing solids can ‘bridge’ above a hole. Use a funnel/baffle, keep openings ≥ ~1.2–2× max piece size, and avoid sharp internal ledges.

Laser fit.a: Kerf is the width of material removed by the laser. Because kerf is centred on the cut line, holes cut larger and parts cut smaller than your file. Start with your lab’s suggested kerf and adjust after testing.

Laser fit.q: My joints are too tight—what do I change?
Laser fit.a: Move Fit towards Loose first. If still tight, increase clearance slightly or update kerf (if kerf is underestimated).

Laser fit.q: My joints are too loose—what do I change?
Laser fit.a: Move Fit towards Tight. Decrease clearance slightly, and ensure thickness is correct.

Laser fit.q: Why are holes the wrong size?
Laser fit.a: Kerf makes holes larger. If you need an accurate hole size, draw it slightly smaller (compensation depends on kerf).

Preview.a: Use Fit-to-view. v0.5 auto-fits on first render and keeps your manual zoom after you adjust.

Project.a: Stacking + one-by-one = Card Shoe. Flowing + counted = Rotary Wheel. Flowing + fun/tolerant = Plinko. Multiple categories = Divider Rack.
Not always. Friction fit can work, but tolerances are tight. For reliability, consider screws/bolts or a few glue points. Prototyping and iteration are normal.
Plywood/MDF is forgiving. Acrylic is brittle—avoid over-tight press fits.

reason.flowingCounted: Best for counted dispensing (one per turn)
reason.flowingTolerant: More tolerant to irregular shapes; good first prototype

warnings.title: Warnings
warnings.kerfTooBig: Kerf is greater than or equal to thickness. Joints may not work.
warnings.clearanceLarge: Joint clearance looks large for this thickness. Parts may be loose.
warnings.slotInvalid: Slot dimensions are invalid or exceed the front panel.
warnings.minTabs: Min tabs is less than 3. Joints may be weak or misaligned.
warnings.vagueClientContext: Requirements check: Client & context looks vague. Add who/where/how it will be used (e.g., ‘personal desk use at home’).
warnings.vagueProblemStatement: Requirements check: Problem statement looks vague. Describe a measurable pain (jams, mess, inconsistent portions, hard access).
warnings.vagueStorageTarget: Requirements check: Storage target has no number. Add a count/grams/volume (e.g., ‘150 cards’).
warnings.vagueDispenseTarget: Requirements check: Dispense target detail looks vague. Add what ‘one dispense’ means (e.g., ‘1 candy per turn’).
warnings.flowingBridgingRisk: Design review: Bridging/jam risk for flowing items. Openings/funnels may be too close to max piece size. Fix: increase internal width/depth, reduce max piece size, or prototype with looser openings.
warnings.rotaryPocketWallsThin: Design review: Rotary wheel pocket walls may be too thin. Fix: reduce pocket count or increase overall size/thickness.
warnings.cardShoeFrontTooTall: Design review: Card shoe front height looks high. Risk: multiple cards may spill. Fix: reduce Front height.
warnings.cardShoeFrontTooShort: Design review: Card shoe front height looks low. Risk: cards may jam / be hard to pull. Fix: increase Front height.
warnings.tallWallsFlexRisk: Design review: Tall walls with thin material can flex/warp. Fix: increase thickness, increase tab count, or reduce height.
warnings.paddingTooSmall: Design review: Layout padding looks small. Risk: parts may overlap or be hard to cut cleanly. Fix: increase Padding.

footer.tip: Tip: If you deploy this on GitHub Pages, it runs client-side and doesn’t need a server.

dispenseType.title: Dispense type
dispenseType.short: Stacking = cards/tiles. Flowing = dry solids only.
dispenseType.meaning: This affects what mechanisms make sense and how the opening should work.
decide: If you are dispensing flat items, choose stacking.
pitfalls: Flowing is not recommended for cards.
wrong: Choosing flowing for cards can cause jams and unstable output.
dispenseType.example: Example: Trading cards → Stacking. Rice/beans (dry) → Flowing.

storageTarget.title: Storage target
storageTarget.short: A planning note: how many items you want to store.
storageTarget.meaning: This doesn’t change geometry directly; it helps students think about capacity.
decide: Write an approximate count (or total height/stack).
pitfalls: Don’t treat this as the real dimension input — use W/D/H below.
wrong: If you only set this and not dimensions, the design won’t match your items.

dispenseTarget.title: Dispense target
dispenseTarget.short: A planning note: how you want it to dispense.
dispenseTarget.meaning: This helps you choose an opening and mechanism, not the final dimensions.
decide: Describe the user action (pull 1 card, shake to pour, etc.).
pitfalls: If you want 1-at-a-time dispensing, mechanism matters more than capacity.
wrong: A mismatch between mechanism and target can cause multiple items to dispense.
dispenseTarget.example: Example: ‘Pull 1 card from a front slot’.

mechanism.title: Mechanism
mechanism.short: Chooses a mechanism and sets the underlying preset.
mechanism.meaning: Mechanism is the student-friendly name; Preset is the generator template.
decide: Pick the one that matches how you want to access/dispense.
typical: Open-front tray is simplest to build and use.
pitfalls: Slot mechanisms require valid slot dimensions.
wrong: Wrong mechanism can block access or dispense too fast.
mechanism.example: Example: Classroom card tray → Open-front tray.

clientContext.title: Client & context
clientContext.short: Who is it for and where will it be used?
clientContext.meaning: This drives clearer requirements and more realistic testing.
decide: Write a concrete use context (desk, classroom, workshop).
typical: Personal desk use; shared classroom demo; workshop bench.
pitfalls: Avoid vague words like ‘somewhere’ or ‘maybe’.
wrong: If context is vague, success criteria and tests will be vague too.
clientContext.example: Example: Personal use at desk; dispensing into a small cup.

problemStatement.title: Problem statement
problemStatement.meaning: A good problem statement makes it easier to pick a mechanism and write success metrics.
decide: Describe the current pain: messy, inconsistent portions, hard access, jams.
typical: Inconsistent portions; messy storage; hard to grab one item.
pitfalls: Avoid ‘nice’ / ‘better’ without saying what changes.
wrong: If the problem is unclear, the design can’t be evaluated.
problemStatement.example: Example: ‘Portions vary a lot; I want 1 candy per turn.’

constraints.title: Constraints acknowledgement
constraints.meaning: These are locked rules for the assignment (no coins, no liquids, personal use).
decide: Check the boxes to confirm you understand the rules.
pitfalls: If any are not met, the project may be out of scope.
wrong: You may build something that cannot be submitted.
constraints.example: Example: Dry solids only; no coin mechanisms.

successMetrics.title: Success metrics
successMetrics.meaning: Metrics turn a vague goal into a testable prototype.
decide: Choose metrics you can test with a simple table.
pitfalls: Avoid metrics you can’t measure in class.
wrong: If you can’t measure it, you can’t improve it.
successMetrics.example: Example: ≤1 jam per 20 dispenses; ±1 item per action.

irregularShape.title: Irregular shape
irregularShape.meaning: Irregular solids bridge/jam more; mechanisms need larger openings and gentler funnels.
decide: Turn on if pieces vary a lot in shape.
typical: Off for uniform candies; on for mixed snacks.
pitfalls: If unsure, turn it on and prototype with loose fit.
wrong: Too-tight openings can cause bridging and jams.

mechanismJustification.title: Justification
mechanismJustification.short: Explain why you chose this mechanism.
mechanismJustification.meaning: This is required for learning outcomes (not autopilot).
decide: Write 1–2 sentences linking requirements → mechanism.
typical: Chosen because it matches counted/one-by-one and reduces jams.
pitfalls: Avoid repeating the mechanism name without reasons.
wrong: Without justification, the project pack export stays locked.
mechanismJustification.example: Example: ‘Plinko tolerates irregular pieces and is easy to test.’

exportAllLanguages.title: Export all languages
exportAllLanguages.short: Include translated docs in the zip.
exportAllLanguages.meaning: When enabled, the pack adds docs/translations/<lang>/... for EN/繁/简.
decide: Turn on for classroom sharing or instructor review.
typical: Off for personal use; on for teaching.
pitfalls: Larger zip size.
wrong: Not an issue; it only affects docs.
exportAllLanguages.example: Example: Export EN + 繁體 + 简体 for students.

preset.title: Preset
preset.short: The template used to generate panels and cutouts.
preset.meaning: Different presets add or remove features (slot, window, lid, etc.).
decide: Choose the closest template, then adjust optional parameters.
pitfalls: Some options only apply to specific presets.
wrong: A preset mismatch can create missing/extra panels.

dimensionMode.title: Dimension mode
dimensionMode.short: Are W/D/H internal (inside space) or external (outside size)?
dimensionMode.meaning: Internal is best when you care about fitting items. External is best when you must fit a footprint.
decide: Pick Internal unless you have a strict outside size constraint.
pitfalls: Switching mode without re-checking thickness changes the effective cavity size.
wrong: Wrong mode can make the cavity too small even if numbers look correct.
dimensionMode.example: Example: A 63mm-wide card needs Internal width slightly above 63mm.

innerWidth.title: Inner width (mm)
innerWidth.meaning: This is the width available for your items.
decide: Measure item width, then add clearance (wiggle room).
typical: Cards: item width + 1–3mm (depends on sleeve and tolerance).
pitfalls: Too tight can jam; too loose can cause tilting.
wrong: Too small → items don’t fit. Too large → items rattle/lean.

innerDepth.title: Inner depth (mm)
innerDepth.meaning: Depth mostly affects capacity and stability.
decide: Set depth to item depth plus a little clearance.
pitfalls: Very deep trays can make it hard to grab items.
wrong: Too shallow → items stick out. Too deep → wasted material/space.

innerHeight.title: Inner height (mm)
innerHeight.meaning: Height controls capacity (how tall the stack can be).
decide: Choose a height that matches your storage target.
typical: Card stacks: depends on count and card thickness.
pitfalls: If height is too tall, stacks can lean unless constrained.
wrong: Too low → items don’t fit. Too high → less stable.
innerHeight.example: Example: 150 cards might be ~45–60mm tall (depends on cards).

thickness.title: Thickness (mm)
thickness.meaning: Thickness affects outside size, joint geometry, and fit rules.
decide: Measure your sheet with calipers if possible.
pitfalls: Nominal ‘3mm’ material is often 2.8–3.2mm.
wrong: Wrong thickness makes joints misfit and dimensions inaccurate.
thickness.example: Example: If your sheet measures 2.9mm, enter 2.9.

fit.title: Fit (tight → loose)
fit.short: A quick preset that sets Joint clearance for you.
fit.meaning: Fit is easier than picking an exact clearance when you’re starting.
decide: Use Loose for student builds; use Tight only after you’ve calibrated.
typical: Loose is often the best classroom default.
pitfalls: If kerf is unknown, even ‘Normal’ may be too tight.
wrong: Too tight → hard assembly. Too loose → wobble/gaps.
fit.example: Example: Start with Loose, then adjust clearance by 0.05mm if needed.

sheetWidth.title: Sheet width (mm)
sheetWidth.short: Used for laying out parts on your material.
sheetWidth.meaning: This doesn’t change the box size, only how panels are arranged.
decide: Enter the usable width of your sheet (after margins).
pitfalls: If too small, layout may overflow or pack poorly.
wrong: Wrong sheet width can cause overlaps or unexpected panel ordering.

margin.title: Margin (mm)
margin.short: Empty space around the outside edge of the sheet.
margin.meaning: Useful to avoid clamps, warped edges, or charred borders.
decide: Use a margin if your laser bed has edge constraints.
pitfalls: Too large wastes material.
wrong: Too small can put cuts too close to the sheet edge.

padding.title: Padding (mm)
padding.short: Spacing between panels in the layout.
padding.meaning: Padding helps prevent scorching and makes parts easier to remove.
decide: Increase if your laser burns edges or if parts are hard to separate.
pitfalls: Too much padding can push layout beyond the sheet width.
wrong: Too small can make parts overlap or touch.

stroke.title: Stroke (mm)
stroke.short: SVG stroke width used for rendering.
stroke.meaning: Many laser workflows cut the path centerline, not stroke thickness.
decide: Leave at 0.2 unless your workflow needs a different preview stroke.
pitfalls: Some software may interpret stroke thickness visually; confirm your cut settings.
wrong: If your laser uses stroke width, verify settings before cutting.

labelsToggle.title: Labels
labelsToggle.short: Engraved panel labels to help assembly.
labelsToggle.meaning: Labels are useful during prototyping and teaching.
decide: Turn on for classroom builds; turn off for final clean parts.
pitfalls: Engraving increases laser time.
wrong: If you don’t want engraved text, turn this off.
labelsToggle.example: Example: Keep labels on for first prototype.

lid.title: Lid
lid.short: Adds lid panels (only for box_with_lid preset).
lid.meaning: The lid is generated as additional panels in the layout.
decide: Enable only if you need a closing top.
pitfalls: A lid increases material usage and assembly complexity.
wrong: If enabled on other presets, it may be ignored.
lid.example: Example: For a travel box, enable Lid.

holdingTabs.title: Holding tabs
holdingTabs.short: Small bridges that keep parts attached after cutting.
holdingTabs.meaning: Tabs prevent parts from shifting or falling through honeycomb beds.
decide: Enable if your parts move after cuts, or if you want safer handling.
typical: Off for clean cuts; On for thin or small parts.
pitfalls: You must cut/sand tabs after the laser run.
wrong: Too few tabs → parts drop. Too many → lots of cleanup.
holdingTabs.example: Example: Enable tabs for acrylic to prevent pieces shifting.

tabWidth.title: Tab width (mm)
tabWidth.short: How wide each holding tab bridge is.
tabWidth.meaning: Wider tabs hold better but require more cleanup.
decide: Pick a width your material can survive without snapping.
pitfalls: Too thin can break during cutting; too thick is hard to remove.
wrong: Broken tabs → parts fall; oversized tabs → lots of sanding.

kerf.title: Kerf (mm)
kerf.meaning: Kerf changes the real size of tabs/slots after cutting.
decide: Run the Fit Test once per material + laser settings.
typical: Often ~0.15–0.25mm, but it varies a lot.
pitfalls: Changing power/speed changes kerf.
wrong: Kerf too small → joints too tight. Kerf too big → joints too loose.

clearance.title: Joint clearance (mm)
clearance.meaning: Clearance tunes how easily tabs slide into slots.
decide: Adjust in small steps (e.g. 0.05mm) based on a test cut.
pitfalls: Clearance can’t fix an incorrect thickness input.
wrong: Too tight → hard assembly/tearing. Too loose → wobble/gaps.
clearance.example: Example: If joints are tight, try 0.10 → 0.15mm.

calSet.title: Calibration set
calSet.short: Which list of clearances to include in the Fit Test.
calSet.meaning: Student is shorter; Full includes more fine steps.
decide: Use Student for class. Use Full when dialing in a perfect fit.
pitfalls: Too many options can confuse first-time users.
wrong: If the test doesn’t include the value you need, switch to Full.
calSet.example: Example: Start with Student, then switch to Full if needed.

fingerWidth.title: Target tab width (mm)
fingerWidth.short: Approximate width of each finger along a joint edge.
fingerWidth.meaning: This affects how many fingers appear on an edge.
decide: Leave auto unless you need a specific look/strength.
pitfalls: Very small fingers are fragile; very large fingers reduce alignment.
wrong: Too small → weak tabs. Too large → joints can twist.
fingerWidth.example: Example: Try 10mm for a balanced look.

minTabs.title: Min tabs
minTabs.short: Minimum number of tabs on each joint edge.
minTabs.meaning: More tabs usually means better alignment and strength.
decide: Keep at 3+ unless the edge is very short.
pitfalls: Too many tabs on a short edge creates tiny fragile features.
wrong: Too few tabs → weak joint. Too many → fragile or messy cuts.
minTabs.example: Example: Min tabs 3 for small trays.

frontHeight.title: Front height (mm)
frontHeight.short: How tall the front panel is (tray_open_front).
frontHeight.meaning: Lowering the front makes it easier to grab items.
decide: Set a front height that keeps items in place but allows access.
typical: Auto or roughly 1/2 to 3/4 of inner height.
pitfalls: Too low can let items fall out.
wrong: Too high → hard to grab. Too low → poor retention.

scoop.title: Scoop
scoop.short: Adds a scoop cutout for easier grabbing (tray_open_front).
scoop.meaning: A scoop removes material from the front opening.
decide: Enable if fingers need help to reach the bottom of the tray.
pitfalls: Scoops reduce front strength.
wrong: Overly large scoops can weaken the front panel.
scoop.example: Example: Enable scoop for small parts bins.

scoopRadius.title: Scoop radius (mm)
scoopRadius.meaning: Larger radius makes a gentler curve.
decide: Use a radius that fits within the front opening.
pitfalls: Too large may intersect joints or edges.
wrong: If geometry overlaps, reduce radius or depth.

scoopDepth.title: Scoop depth (mm)
scoopDepth.short: How deep the scoop cut goes.
scoopDepth.meaning: Depth controls how much material is removed from the front.
decide: Increase if access is still hard; decrease if too weak.
pitfalls: Too deep can cut into the bottom area.
wrong: Over-deep scoops weaken the panel.

slotWidth.title: Slot width (mm)
slotWidth.meaning: Slot width controls what can pass through.
decide: Set slightly larger than item width if items slide out sideways.
typical: Cards: near card width, but constrained to prevent double-feed.
pitfalls: Too wide can allow multiple items to escape.
wrong: If too narrow, items jam. If too wide, uncontrolled dispensing.
slotWidth.example: Example: 63mm cards → slot width 60–62mm depending on mechanism.

slotHeight.title: Slot height (mm)
slotHeight.meaning: Slot height controls thickness clearance and how many items can slip out.
decide: Keep low for single-item dispensing.
pitfalls: Too tall can allow 2 items at once.
wrong: Too small → jams. Too large → double-feed.

slotY.title: Slot Y (mm)
slotY.short: Vertical position of the slot from the bottom.
slotY.meaning: Controls where the opening sits relative to the item stack.
decide: Place it where the stack naturally presses the front.
pitfalls: Slot + height must stay within the front panel.
wrong: Invalid slot placement will be warned/ignored.
slotY.example: Example: If inner height is 80mm, try slotY 30–40mm.

dispenseTargetType.title: Dispense target
dispenseTargetType.meaning: This helps auto-select a mechanism and default settings.
decide: Cards: One-at-a-time or Grab stack.
Candy: Counted (per turn) or Fun chute.
pitfalls: If you pick counted but want random pours, choose Fun chute instead.
wrong: Wrong target can pick a mechanism that doesn’t match your goal.
dispenseTargetType.example: Example: 1 candy per click → Counted (per turn).

cardWidth.title: Card width (mm)
cardWidth.meaning: Used in Student Mode auto-design to size the cavity.
decide: Measure your real item; don’t assume standard sizes.
pitfalls: Too small jams; too large lets cards rotate/tilt.
wrong: If cards don’t fit, increase width or clearance.

cardHeight.title: Card height (mm)
cardHeight.meaning: Often sets depth for card mechanisms.
decide: Measure the longer side of the card.
pitfalls: If depth is too small, the deck won’t sit correctly.
wrong: If the deck sticks out, increase depth or reduce capacity.

capacityCards.title: Capacity (cards)
capacityCards.short: How many cards the design should hold.
capacityCards.meaning: Used in Student Mode to estimate stack height.
decide: Pick a realistic target; overfilling increases friction.
pitfalls: Overfilling can jam dispensing mechanisms.
wrong: If loading is hard, reduce capacity or increase height.

maxPieceSize.title: Max piece size (mm)
maxPieceSize.short: Largest candy/piece size for flowing solids.
maxPieceSize.meaning: Openings and chutes should be sized from this (worst case).
decide: Measure the biggest piece in your mix.
pitfalls: Undersizing causes jams/bridging.
wrong: If it jams, increase openings/chutes and reduce sharp ledges.

dividerBays.title: Divider bays
dividerBays.short: Number of lanes in the divider rack.
decide: Pick how many categories you need.
pitfalls: Too many bays makes thin dividers.
wrong: If dividers are fragile, reduce bay count.

pocketCount.title: Pocket count
pocketCount.short: Number of pockets in the rotary wheel.
pocketCount.meaning: More pockets = smaller turn per dispense.
decide: Use fewer pockets for stronger walls.
pitfalls: Too many pockets makes thin walls and weaker discs.
wrong: If wheel is weak, reduce pocket count.

axleDiameter.title: Axle diameter (mm)
axleDiameter.short: Diameter of dowel/bolt used as the wheel axle.
axleDiameter.meaning: Match your available hardware for smooth rotation.
decide: Measure the real axle if possible.
pitfalls: Too tight increases friction; too loose wobbles.
wrong: If it binds, increase the axle hole slightly.

rampCount.title: Ramp count
rampCount.short: Number of ramp strips in the plinko mechanism.
rampCount.meaning: More ramps slows and guides falling pieces.
decide: Use more ramps for smaller pieces.
pitfalls: Too many ramps increases cutting time.
wrong: If it drops too fast, increase ramp count.

troubleshooting.title: Troubleshooting
troubleshooting.short: Common symptoms and what to change.
troubleshooting.meaning: Use these quick checks before re-cutting a full design.
wrong: Too tight: increase Joint clearance by ~0.05mm or verify kerf with Fit Test.
Too loose: decrease Joint clearance by ~0.05mm.
Wrong size: confirm Dimension mode and Thickness.
